hackathon-description-text: will take place March 31st through April 2nd in Earl Gregg Swem Library. Teams will start hacking Friday evening after the Opening Ceremony and continue working until Sunday morning at 9 AM. All submissions

hackathon-judges.judge-role: Chair and Associate Professor, W&M CS Department

hackathon-eligibility:
Any current college student, or anyone who has graduated in the last 12 months is eligible to attend TribeHacks.
The maximum team size is 4 people.
hackathon-rules:
All participants must follow the 
No code may be written before the start of the event
Failure to comply with the above rules may lead to disqualification and/or removal from the event.

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Use your tech skills for good and hack online harassment! Build a software solution that can help reduce the frequency and/or severity of online harassment. Members of the winning team receive Hack Harassment Battery Packs!
$250 in AWS credits to each member of the winning team
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Amazon Web Services - Best Use of AWS

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Each winner will receive a prize kit including a Nike pullover, wireless headphones, and an Amazon gift card.

hackathon-location-google-maps: https://maps.google.com/?q=400 Landrum Dr, Williamsburg, VA 23185, USA

hackathon-judging-criteria.judging-criterion: How complicated is the hack on a technical level? What algorithms or frameworks are used? Were technical challenges solved in an elegant way (given the time limit)?
Is the hack creative? Is is a new idea, or maybe a new spin on a tried and true formula?
Is the hack intuitive? Could someone use it without a ton of explanation? Is the hack attractive such that people would actually want to use it?
Does the hack solve a real world problem? Could it be viable in today's market?

How many of the teams goals were actually implemented? A project with lofty ideas but little implementation should not receive as high a rating as a project that has many features actually implemented.
